block.p: Textiles by Women
Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology, Seventh Avenue at 27th Street; (212) 217-5800.

''A Woman's Hand: Designing Textiles in America, 1945-1969,'' an exhibition of 75 items of clothing and cloth, starts on Tuesday and runs through Jan. 13. The printed, woven and knitted textiles include those designed by Ray Eames, Anni Albers, Dorothy Liebes and Tammis Keefe. Open Tuesday through Friday, noon to 8 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. No charge.
Textiles by Women
Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology, Seventh Avenue at 27th Street; (212) 217-5800.

''A Woman's Hand: Designing Textiles in America, 1945-1969,'' an exhibition of 75 items of clothing and cloth, starts on Tuesday and runs through Jan. 13. The printed, woven and knitted textiles include those designed by Ray Eames, Anni Albers, Dorothy Liebes and Tammis Keefe. Open Tuesday through Friday, noon to 8 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. No charge.
On Wednesday at 6 p.m., there will be a panel discussion on women who design textiles. Reservations are required. Tickets, $10.
An Architect on Stage
Wallach Art Gallery, Schermerhorn Hall at Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street; (212) 854-2877.

''Architect of Dreams: The Theatrical Vision of Joseph Urban,'' an exhibition of set designs, watercolors, models and architectural drawings on view through Dec. 16, will look at Joseph Urban's stage designs for theater and opera productions. Mr. Urban designed sets for 168 productions between 1915 and 1931, including those for the Ziegfeld Follies and the Metropolitan Opera. Open Wednesday through Saturday, 1 to 5 p.m. No charge.
Antiques on Park
Wallace Hall at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street; (212) 288-3588.
A show and sale of furniture, paintings, jewelry, garden statuary, rugs, maps and clocks opens tonight at 6 p.m. with a preview party. Tickets are $50.
The show will continue tomorrow and Saturday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m., and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission is $10.
Garden Days
New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx; (718) 817-8700.

''Get Up and Garden,'' a series of demonstrations and talks, will take place on Saturday from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Among the events will be a talk on fall lawn care, at 11:30 a.m.; a demonstration on growing winter vegetables, at 1 p.m.; and a hands-on workshop on what to do in winter to prepare perennial borders for springtime, at 1:30 p.m. Garden admission is $10; students and those 65 and older, $7.50; children 2 to 12, $4.50. There is no additional charge for the programs.
A book and bulb sale will be held on Saturday and Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.

A show in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, depicting a Japanese autumn garden, opens tomorrow and continues through Nov. 19. It will feature bonsai, Japanese maples and conifers, and, after Nov. 1, chrysanthemums. The garden is open Tuesday through Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Crafts on Columbus
Columbus Avenue, from 77th to 81st Street; (212) 866-2239.

On Saturday and Sunday, and again on Oct. 21 and 22, 150 artisans will sell such handmade items as silk clothing, glass vases, silver jewelry, wooden toys, ceramic platters and leather handbags. Open 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. No charge for admission.
Gramercy Park Antiques
69th Regiment Armory, 26th Street at Lexington Avenue; (212) 255-0020.

One hundred dealers will offer such antique items as textiles, mirrors, vintage tubs, chandeliers and lighting fixtures, in a show and sale today through Saturday. Open today and tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m., and Saturday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is $10.
Thoroughly Modern Seating
Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street; (212) 849-8400.

''Masterpieces from the Vitra Design Museum: Furnishing the Modern Era,'' an exhibition of 100 pieces of furniture, continues through Feb. 4. The furniture, primarily chairs, couches and other seating dating from the 1850's, is shown along with photographs and catalogs from the Vitra Design Museum in Weil am Rhein, Germany.
Some of the designers represented in the exhibition are Le Corbusier, Frank Lloyd Wright, Charles and Ray Eames, Eero Saarinen, Gio Ponti, Robert Venturi, Arne Jacobson and Hans Wegner.
Open Tuesday, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Wednesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Admission is $8; students and those 62 and older, $5; members and children under 12, no charge.
